text:
üìö Recommended Reading

Alternative Property-Right Structures and the Incentives They Create
Private ownership is only one way to assign rights to use resources. Other arrangements include:

State-property regimes: the government holds title and controls access and use.
Common-property regimes: a defined community jointly owns and manages the resource.
Res nullius / open-access regimes: no party holds ownership or control over access.

Each arrangement shapes user behavior‚Äîand therefore resource outcomes‚Äîin different ways.
State property exists, to some extent, in nearly every nation. National parks and wilderness areas are common examples. These systems can face efficiency problems when the goals or incentives of officials who design or enforce the rules do not align with society‚Äôs broader interests.
Common property refers to shared resources governed collectively rather than by individual private owners. Rights to use may be formal (spelled out in law) or informal (rooted in custom or tradition). How well common-property systems perform‚Äîboth economically and ecologically‚Äîdepends on the quality of collectively chosen rules and on compliance with those rules. Although there are notable success stories, breakdowns are, unfortunately, even more frequent. Successful cases often rest on reciprocity and trust within the user group.
A well-known success is Switzerland‚Äôs alpine grazing system. While farmland is typically private, grazing rights on Alpine meadows have long been managed as common property. An association of users sets specific limits on livestock to deter overgrazing. Membership has historically been stable, with rights and responsibilities passing down through families. That continuity supported trust and reciprocal behavior, which in turn sustained compliance and the rules‚Äô effectiveness.
Such stability is not guaranteed, especially under rising population pressure. In Mawelle, Sri Lanka, villagers initially created a sophisticated rotating system of fishing rights to distribute access to prime locations and times while protecting the stock. Over time, population growth and the entry of outsiders both increased demand and eroded cohesion and trust. The customary rules became unenforceable, leading predictably to overuse of the fishery and lower incomes.
Res nullius (open access) resources, by definition, lack a mechanism to control entry because no person or group has the legal authority to do so. Consequently, use proceeds on a first-come, first-served basis. Such open-access settings underpin what is commonly called the ‚Äútragedy of the open-access commons.‚Äù
Open-access common-pool resources are shared stocks that are nonexclusive (anyone can exploit them) and rivalous (one user‚Äôs harvest reduces what‚Äôs left for others). The American bison illustrates the consequences. In the early United States, bison were so abundant that unrestricted hunting posed no immediate problem: people could readily obtain hides and meat, and one hunter‚Äôs aggressiveness did not meaningfully raise the time and effort others needed. When scarcity was absent, open access did not undermine efficiency. As demand rose and the herd shrank, however, each incremental unit of hunting effort required more time and work to achieve an extra harvest.







Bison Harvesting


A graphical analysis clarifies how different property-rights regimes (and the harvest levels they induce) affect economic surplus (benefits to consumers and producers net of costs). In the top panel, total revenue equals the (assumed constant) bison price times harvested quantity at each effort level; the upward-sloping total cost curve reflects higher total costs as effort increases (with constant marginal cost in this example). The total surplus at any effort is the vertical gap between the total revenue and total cost curves.
In the bottom panel, the marginal revenue curve slopes downward‚Äîeven though price is constant‚Äîbecause greater effort reduces the population, which lowers harvest per unit of effort. The efficient effort level, \(E^{*}\), maximizes surplus. That can be seen two equivalent ways: (1) in totals, \(E^{*}\) maximizes the distance between total benefits and total costs; (2) in margins, \(E^{*}\) occurs where marginal revenue equals marginal cost, with marginal cost capturing the extra cost of the last unit of effort. The lower-panel curves are derived from the relationships shown in the upper panel.
Under open access, unrestricted entry makes the outcome inefficient. Individual hunters lack an incentive to restrain effort to protect the shared surplus. Instead, they continue to harvest until total benefits equal total costs‚Äîthe open-access effort \(E_{OA}\). Overuse occurs because individuals cannot appropriate the surplus; additional effort dissipates it. Losses that could be avoided by an exclusive owner‚Äîor by effective collective governance‚Äîare not avoided when access is free.
Two general features of the open-access outcome follow:

With sufficiently high demand, overexploitation is the result.
The surplus is dissipated: no one captures it, and it disappears.

The mechanism is straightforward: unlimited access removes the incentive to conserve. An owner able to exclude others has reason to maintain the herd at an efficient size to preserve surplus, which also reduces the time and effort needed per unit of harvest. By contrast, an open-access hunter gains little from self-restraint because any surplus preserved would be partly taken by others who keep harvesting. Hence, when resources are scarce, open access leads to inefficient allocation. In combination with habitat conversion to farms and pasture, this dynamic drove the Great Plains bison herds to the brink of extinction.


Community-Devised Governance of the Commons (Ostrom‚Äôs Insights)
An alternative to relying on private ownership or top-down regulation is for resource users to craft their own agreements to avoid the tragedy of the commons. Elinor Ostrom, who received the 2009 Nobel Prize in Economics, documented how many communities govern shared resources through self-organized, cooperative arrangements without privatization or heavy state control. Local users often possess context-specific knowledge‚Äîabout ecology, seasons, and customs‚Äîthat regulators may lack when setting access fees or harvest limits. They also understand that short-run individual gain can trigger long-run ecological and economic collapse, so they adopt precautionary rules to sustain the resource.
Cooperative local management tends to work when most users participate in designing the rules; when monitoring is conducted by people accountable to users who regularly assess conditions and compliance; when disputes can be resolved quickly and inexpensively; when rules are adapted to local ecology, culture, and technology; and when sanctions are graduated, starting modestly and escalating for repeated violations.
Ostrom‚Äôs approach can complement government rather than replace it, especially for large-scale commons where layered institutions are helpful. A state or federal agency might administer and enforce an individual transferable quota program, while local fishers co-design allocation rules and handle day-to-day conflicts. The broader lesson is that effective resource governance is participatory, combining local (including Indigenous) knowledge, history, and culture with wider legal and scientific capacity. At national or global scales, government involvement is usually essential, but policies should still respect local variation and incorporate community voices.

References

Tietenberg T. and Lewis L., Chapter 2. The Economic Approach: Property Rights, Externalities, and Environmental Problems, Environmental and Natural Resource Economics (12th Edition)
Harris J. and Roach B., Chapter 3. Theory of Environmental Externality, Environmental and Natural Resource Economics: A Contemporary Approach (5th Edition)

title: Lecture 9
text:
Why Discount the Future?
The discount rate answers a fundamental question:

At what rate should society discount future benefits so that sacrificing one unit of consumption today is fairly balanced by gains to future well-being?


This rate reflects how we value the future relative to the present, and it can be determined in two main ways:

Through ethical principles about intergenerational welfare ‚Üí the social (prescriptive) approach

Through observed market behavior and the opportunity cost of capital ‚Üí the market-based (descriptive) approach

Over 100 years, \(r = 3.4\%\) yields a PV about one-seventh of that at \(r = 1.4\%\)

Implication: The chosen discount rate can reverse policy conclusions for long-horizon issues (e.g., climate)

‚ÄúWhat should be the fair tradeoff between present and future welfare?‚Äù


Sets parameters based on ethical principles of intergenerational fairness, not on market behavior

\(\eta\): reflects inequality aversion ‚Äî society places less value on extra income for richer future generations

\(g\): assumes modest long-run growth (e.g., 1‚Äì1.5%), consistent with sustainability concerns


Result: Low SDR (‚âà 1‚Äì2%) ‚Üí greater weight on future generations and stronger justification for early climate action

title: Lecture 9
text:
üí° The Rule of 72
A simple way to estimate how long it takes for a value to double given a fixed annual growth (or interest) rate.



\[
\text{Years to Double} \approx \frac{72}{r}
\]
where \(r\) is the annual percentage rate (not in decimal form).

The higher the rate of return, the faster the doubling.

Works well for rates between 2% and 15%.

Useful for understanding economic/financial growth, inflation, or discounting.

Example: If the economy grows at 3% per year, its size doubles in about 24 years.

What Is Cost‚ÄìBenefit Analysis (CBA)?

CBA evaluates whether the present value of benefits exceeds the present value of costs for a project or policy.


All costs and benefits are expressed in today‚Äôs dollars using a discount rate (\(r\))

Enables meaningful comparison of outcomes occurring at different times

Helps allocate scarce resources efficiently across competing alternatives

How to balance economic, health, and environmental goals
Whether policy benefits justify the present value of implementation costs

title: Lecture 9
section: Steps in Conducting a PV-Based CBA
text:
Steps in Conducting a PV-Based CBA


List all costs and benefits over time

Quantify each stream in monetary terms

Discount each future value to its present value using rate \(r\)

Sum PVs of costs and benefits:

\[
PV_B = \sum_t \frac{B_t}{(1 + r)^t}, \qquad PV_C = \sum_t \frac{C_t}{(1 + r)^t}
\]

Compute PV Net Benefits and PV Benefit‚ÄìCost Ratio

Compare across policy alternatives, including a baseline (no action)

title: Lecture 9
text:
üßÆ Decision Criteria (Using Present Value)


1Ô∏è‚É£ PV of Net Benefits
\[
PV_{NB} = PV_B - PV_C
\]

\(PV_{NB}\) (Present Value of Net Benefits) measures total welfare change in today‚Äôs dollars.

Adds up all future benefits (\(B_t\)) and costs (\(C_t\)), converted into present value using the discount rate (\(r\)).   

If \(PV_{NB} > 0\), benefits exceed costs ‚Üí policy improves total welfare and is worth undertaking.


2Ô∏è‚É£ PV Benefit‚ÄìCost Ratio
\[
PV_{B/C} = \frac{PV_B}{PV_C}
\]

Compares the relative size of discounted benefits and costs.

If \(PV_{B/C} > 1\), benefits outweigh costs in present-value terms.

Useful for comparing multiple projects when budgets are limited.

title: Lecture 9
text:
Opportunity Cost and Efficiency
Even if \(PV_{NB} > 0\):

Another policy might yield a higher \(PV_{NB}\)

Always consider the opportunity cost of choosing one project over another

Economics seeks to maximize \(PV_{NB}\) ‚Äî the condition for dynamic efficiency

title: Lecture 9
text:
Distributional and Ethical Issues ‚öñÔ∏è

CBA aggregates all PV benefits and costs across society
‚Üí ignores who gains and who bears the costs
Example:

PV benefits ‚Üí wealthier households (longer lifespan, better access)
PV costs ‚Üí lower-income communities (energy price hikes)

Even with positive \(PV_{NB}\), may still be inequitable

title: Lecture 9
text:
What Dynamic Efficiency Means

Dynamic efficiency means using resources over time in a way that gives society the greatest total benefit, after accounting for all costs and discounting the future.

It‚Äôs about finding the right balance between using resources today and saving or investing for tomorrow.

Because resources are limited, spending more today means less available later ‚Äî and vice versa.
Dynamic efficiency helps decide how much to invest now in things like renewable energy, infrastructure, or conservation versus how much to consume now for immediate satisfaction.

It ensures society gets the best overall outcome through time, not just the biggest short-term gain.


In short:
A policy is dynamically efficient if there‚Äôs no better way to spread costs and benefits over time that would give society a higher total present value of welfare.

In practice, dynamic efficiency guides how much to invest now (e.g., in renewable energy, conservation, or infrastructure) versus how much to consume now, recognizing that resources used today cannot be used tomorrow.


A policy is dynamically efficient if no other feasible allocation of costs and benefits across time could yield a higher total present value of welfare.

3) Reflection ‚Äî Sample Answer

Why is it hard to agree on a single ‚Äúright‚Äù discount rate?

It‚Äôs hard to agree on a single ‚Äúright‚Äù discount rate because it reflects both ethical values and empirical assumptions.
Ethically, people disagree on how much to value future generations; empirically, economists differ on expected growth, risk, and opportunity cost of capital.

How might uncertainty (e.g., climate damages, tech change) affect the choice of discount rate?

Uncertainty about climate damages or technological change often leads to using a lower or declining discount rate, since future outcomes could be much worse (or better) than expected, and society may want to hedge against catastrophic risks.

In your view, how should economists balance efficiency and fairness between generations?

Economists should balance efficiency (maximizing total welfare) with fairness (ensuring future generations are not undervalued).
This means giving sufficient weight to the future ‚Äî using discount rates that reflect both economic realities and intergenerational responsibility.
Economists should balance efficiency and fairness by recognizing that market-based efficiency alone often underrepresents future generations, who have no voice in current decisions.
Purely efficiency-focused models discount the future heavily, favoring short-term gains, while fairness requires giving moral weight to people who will live decades from now.
A balanced approach would use efficiency to guide resource allocation within generations, but apply ethical or declining discount rates to account for long-term sustainability and irreversible environmental losses.
This means accepting slightly lower present efficiency if it prevents large welfare losses or ecological risks for future generations ‚Äî a tradeoff that aligns with the idea of intergenerational equity.

Present Value (PV) Formula
Let \(X_n\) be a cost/benefit received in \(n\) years and \(r\) the discount rate:
\[
\text{PV}(X_n) \;=\; \frac{X_n}{(1+r)^{\,n}}
\]

Further in time (\(n\uparrow\)) ‚Üí PV falls

Higher discount rate (\(r\uparrow\)) ‚Üí PV falls




Tip

\(r=3\%, n=10 \Rightarrow \text{PV}=\$74.41\)

\(r=7\%, n=10 \Rightarrow \text{PV}=\$50.83\)

üí° Quick Detour: The Rule of 72
A simple way to estimate how long it takes for a value to double given a fixed annual growth (or interest) rate.



\[
\text{Years to Double} \approx \frac{72}{r}
\]
where \(r\) is the annual percentage rate (not in decimal form).

The higher the rate of return, the faster the doubling.

Works well for rates between 2% and 15%.

Useful for understanding economic/financial growth, inflation, or discounting.

Example: If the economy grows at 3% per year, its size doubles in about 24 years.

title: Lecture 9
text:
Why Discount the Future?
The discount rate answers a fundamental question:

At what rate should society discount future benefits so that sacrificing one unit of consumption today is fairly balanced by gains to future well-being?


This rate reflects how we value the future relative to the present, and it can be determined in two main ways:

Through ethical principles about intergenerational welfare ‚Üí the social (prescriptive) approach

Through observed market behavior and the opportunity cost of capital ‚Üí the market-based (descriptive) approach

title: Lecture 9
text:
Social Discount Rate (SDR)



\[
\text{SDR} = \rho + \eta \cdot g
\]




\(\rho\): pure rate of time preference ‚Äî captures impatience or preference for present welfare over future welfare

\(\eta\): elasticity of marginal utility of consumption ‚Äî measures how quickly the extra satisfaction (utility) from consumption declines as people become richer

When people are poor, an extra dollar raises happiness a lot

When people are richer, an extra dollar adds little

Inequality aversion: a higher \(\eta\) means society is more sensitive to inequality across generations 

\(g\): growth rate of real consumption ‚Äî the expected pace of income growth over time

title: Lecture 9
text:
1Ô∏è‚É£ Ethical (Prescriptive) Approach

‚ÄúWhat should be the fair tradeoff between present and future welfare?‚Äù


Sets parameters based on ethical principles of intergenerational fairness, not on market behavior

\(\rho\): very low (‚âà 0‚Äì0.1%) ‚Üí future welfare valued almost equally to present welfare

\(\eta\): reflects inequality aversion ‚Äî society places less value on extra income for richer future generations

\(g\): assumes modest long-run growth (e.g., 1‚Äì1.5%), consistent with sustainability concerns


Result: Low SDR (‚âà 1‚Äì2%) ‚Üí greater weight on future generations and stronger justification for early climate action

title: Lecture 9
text:
2Ô∏è‚É£ Market-Based (Descriptive) Approach



Note


The Opportunity Cost of Capital is the return forgone when spending $1 today on a project, instead of investing that same $1 in the best available alternative (for example, in private capital markets or government bonds).





Set \(r \approx\) low-risk market return (e.g., government bonds or average real return on capital)

Logic: Funds spent today could have been invested ‚Äî the opportunity cost of capital determines the appropriate \(r\)

Idea: Society‚Äôs time preference between present and future consumption is revealed through saving, investment, and consumption decisions, as reflected in observed market returns and long-run economic growth.
Caveat: Market rates change over time

Very low in the 2020s; very high in the early 1980s

title: Lecture 9

2Ô∏è‚É£ Market-Based (Descriptive) Approach

‚ÄúHow do markets actually value the future?‚Äù


Sets parameters based on observed economic behavior, not ethical judgments

\(\rho\): higher (‚âà 1‚Äì2%) ‚Äî reflects society‚Äôs revealed time preference in saving and investment decisions

\(\eta\): inferred from market data ‚Äî captures how people trade off consumption and risk over time

\(g\): assumes stronger long-run growth (e.g., 2%), consistent with historical productivity trends


Result: Higher SDR (‚âà 4‚Äì5%) ‚Üí less weight on distant future impacts and supports relatively gradual, cost-efficient mitigation og GHG

Helps allocate scarce resources efficiently across competing alternatives
